Well, the Bible is something of an adventure thriller, Mose floating on the Nile and being rescued by the princess, then exiting Egypt in a hail of frogs and stuff, parting the Red Sea I think it was, climbing up a mountain, throwing down the stone tablets in a fit of anger, wasn't he the guy with burning bush? Then, there's Noah and the whale or a great fish or something, and a whole bunch of other adventure stuff. For sex, there's always King Solomon who always had an eye for the ladies--like his daddy, hehe. The angst and woe of Job and, speaking of Solomon's daddy, David, a lot of whining but a real whizbang story about the sling and stone and the giant and bringing down a kingdom, and there's the lions in the den and what's his name.

 When did I do that and are you stating that I was logical and beat you soundly with logic or are you saying that I was so illogical that you discontinued the argument. The "never say the word" comment is what I was referring to.
 
 As to the design of the bible:
 
 It was never intended to control people as many have stated. I assume that is what you mean by "make people religious" The phrase "make people...." is a statement of control. 
 
 If it had been designed simply as a means of controlling the populace then they could have done a much much much better job of it. 
 
 1) Controling the populace does not fit with the genre. Its genre is a collection of works over a long period of time. That is pretty clear even from a secular archeological perspective. Even The Smithsonian magazine (issue of june 2006, I think, it might also have been may) reports that the gospels themselves were written within about 70 years of the events they describe, more than most secular texts. If you read the article you will see that it clearly does not favor the christian viewpoint yet it concedes this point.
 
 2) The apostles, those held as heros of the faith and those whose stories would use to control are represented in the gospels in a far and away less than good light. Jesus says to peter "get behind me satan", they all run away when jesus is arrested (John runs away naked), during the upper room discourse they are seen arguing over who is the greatest, they are represented time and time again as bumbling, slow witted, and forgetful.
 
 3) The historical documents which document the process of cannonizing scripture and other secular texts from Josephus, pliny the younger, etc, show that the church of the time was concerned that doctrine be equally transmitted to all. If it were controlling one would expect those doctrines to deviate across countries and cultures so as to have the greatest impact on the culture. This is true and was used by the romans and before them the greeks and also the egyptians and even the jews during various reigns.
 
 I could add other arguments for now these will do. Do you have a postion and on what do you base it. 
 
 EF

 This may throw you a bit, but.........wrong.
 
 The bible itself has no power in the life of a man. Christians (most of them anyway) believe it to be The Word of God. God's revelation of himself to man. God is what makes a good man out of you, not the bible.
 
 The appropriate Genre for the bible would be in the tradition of story telling. There are subgenres within the bible. For instance, Psalms and Job are poetic. The letters of paul are personal letters, the gospels are stories, etc.
 
 The question of this thread is : was it designed with that purpose in mind. The answer is no. It may have that effect in some cases, but to say it was designed for that purpose doesn't hold water for the reasons previously stated.
 
 And thank you for the compliment. In a debate forum, I get very used to people being "contrary" so I don't anticipate compliments. My apologies for the mischaracterization.
 
 EF

Actually the bible was not written for a secular readership its a hard book to understand and many untaught, unguided and worse many unstable people twist scripture for their own ends, the bible was not available to a secular readership until rather recently about 500 years ago when a certain monk transcribed it from the original greek & hebrew into german, you can thank the printing press for the so called "liberation" of the bible...personally I think its "pearls thrown to the swine" - not that I am calling any of you pigs, no its a religious term that you may take offense to but really there is no actuall insult there....
 
 The bible previously had only been wrote in greek and hebrew and availible to read in a pre-reformation church where it would be kept chined up.
 
 This served two purposes.
 
 1. That scripture could only be read by those interested enough to go to church, thus most likely Christian
 
 2. Only those who had a good education in the "religious languages" of hebrew and greek could understand it, thus most likely a well taughed well guided Christian.
 
 So your answer is no, its not a book written to bring about conversion, it was writen for the intention of preserving the word of god and teaching, rebuking, correcting and training the man of god....i.e the Christian in righteousness.
 
 Since the reformation and the translation of the bible into every language known to man we have had new so called "christian" churches springing up on every street corner for years there now exists over 33,000 denominations of christianity all with different beliefs and doctrines all based on peoples private interpretation of the bible, and these churches actually encorage private interpretation of the bible even though the bible itself clearly teaches that private interpretation of the bible should be DISCOURAGED..... The bible has been twisted and distorted by many many untaught, unguided and unstable individuals, so much so that its hard enough for someone who believes in God and in Christ to know what to believe any more let alone convert an agnostic or an athiest.

the bible didnt just drop out of the sky pre wrote...it is without doubt a very hard book to understand, you have to remember it was mere men who were trying to transcribe the revealed truth about god, they done it in poem, in song, in stories ect there are things to be taken litteral, things to be taken symbolically, things to be understood in fact and in fiction, it is the word of god in that it reveals the truth about god, but it is the words of men trying to convay that truth.
 
 For example:
 
 "if your eye causes you to sin, cut it out"
 
 litteral or symbolic?
 
 also you have to remember that Christ left us an authority on earth through which he would reveal his truth to us, the bible is only a creation of that authority a tool by which the truth is revealed, by itself it is hard to understand and with all reason you must see that if there is this omnipotant omnipresent eternal god, could you really believe those few books in the bible could easily reveal that god without the teaching and guidence of an eternal and living authroity?

If it's simple to understand then why the contradiction? Why the ambiguous messages?
 
 And I also agree that this thread is daft without being allowed to quote the thing we are talking about! In order for anyone's claims to be validated, they have to draw on evidence for said claims, that's how debating works. If we are not allowed to draw on the one source that relates to the subject, all that is left is meaningless opinion...
 
 edit: typo

But it's not meaningless. I've not read say, any of the Nuremburg Rallies. But if I was to ask for someone's opinion on their intent, I'd sure as hell want them to back it up with quotes.
 
 Indeed, he can't stop me. But in all honesty I'm more concerned with drawing attention to the ludicrousness of his request than rehashing a debate that I've participated in so many times before...

For Phunting: For example: God did not fail in His puropse of giving man a simple revelation that could be understood by all men alike, "even by the simple" (Deut. 29:29; Ps. 119:104, 130; Prov 1;1-4; 2 Tim. 3:15-17). 
 
 If, you are versed in the Scripture you should know that Paul speaks of "the simplicity that is in Christ" (2 Cor. 11;3). And Jesus thanked God that the truths of the Bible were hidden from the worldly wise, who refused to believe, and stated that God has "revealed them unto babes" (Matt. 11l25-27). Now, you may be either worldly wise, and a non believer, and unable to understand its contents, or a babe in the making. We shall soon know by your response if any.

 
 
 If the bible is so simple, why do so many people disagree about it.
 
 Paul might have talked about the 'simplicity' of Christ, but so many people disagree what that 'simplicity' is.

Some of you seam to be trying to convince us that the bible is inert. The bible is a powerful book that strongly influences many many people. Making arguments otherwise is simply an absurd waste of time. 
 
 The absence of scripture in this forum was a refreshing change of pace and I would like to encourage more of this kind of thing in the future. Well done Monster.

 I am deeply distressed by the news of Monsters death and I am not in any way implying any humour. I'm so glad the police found the murder weapon. They might be able to finally solve this cunundrum.

 Ironically the police now suspect the incident might have been an assisted suicide in which the attacker was provoked to secure his own demise. Computers seized during the associated investigation are said to have records that clearly indicating that he was trying to get himself killed. I don't think it was easy to be Monster, I know he was in a good deal of pain in his gut and was having trouble catching his breath. The other monks at the monastery told me of terrible nights where he would howl for hours until tears came to his eyes.  The last thing Monster would wish was that you should feel that way, as he found your arguments most compelling when you were totally ###### off. He used to tell me with a twinkle in his eye "Doc, haz is a veritable cornucopia!" After speaking with you I can only conclude that it was of #### and vinegar. 
 
 I am sorry I should have been clearer, but when I said, your people, I meant girls. (Now I see what he means!)
 
 As far as answers go, I can assure you, he hadn't any. In fact, he really doesn't know anything. He just makes it up as he goes. This is the diabolical nature of predatory lampoonery. 
 
 As for this sticky business of masturbation, I will not defend Monster here with the truth here by telling you that he was quite fond of browsing porn wile he debated you. (Kind of makes you want to take a bath, doesn't it.) It's one of the reasons I never shook his hand, but now, I truly wish I had. 
 
 I believe that monster is watching over us now, from a better place. I can feel his spirit rising up inside of me and I know after reading his simple words that he will be inside of me, forever. 
 
 In closing I think Monster would have liked me to leave you with these thoughts:
 
 http://www.4forums.com/political/showpost.php?p=216403&postcount=102
 
 Followed by: 
 
 So lets dispense with the formalities and get on with it!
 
 Doc

I believe that monster is watching over us now, from a better place. I can feel his spirit rising up inside of me and I know after reading his simple words that he will be inside of me, forever.
